awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Photon-Enabled Atomic Drilling of Graphene for Supercapacitors
awd_abstract_narration:
Supercapacitors have emerged as next-generation high-performance power sources for portable devices used in a wide range of consumer, biomedical, healthcare, and military applications.  It remains a fundamental challenge in supercapacitor design to simultaneously achieve high energy and power densities with a long cycle life.  A porous graphene framework, consisting of a three-dimensional graphene structure containing nano-sized holes and micro-size pores, has emerged as a promising solution to address this challenge due to its superior electrochemical properties.  However, the existing methods for fabricating this graphene framework often rely on thermal chemical etching processes, which suffer from low efficiency and poor controllability due to complex experiments and poor thermal stability of etchants.  This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge for the development of a novel manufacturing strategy using photon-material interactions to realize porous graphene framework fabrication with a high efficiency. This research will have  significant broader impact because of the spillover into literally all economic sectors because of the potential transformative  performance improvement of supercapacitors.  This project also provides an integrated science and engineering training platform for graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students, with particular emphasis on promoting participation of women and underrepresented students in research.

The goal of this project is to establish a novel photon-enabled atomic drilling process to fabricate porous graphene frameworks toward supercapacitor applications. The photon-enabled atomic drilling approach utilizes photons from a nanosecond pulsed laser to initiate atomic drilling of nanoholes in the graphene basal planes for porous graphene framework fabrication with high efficiency and controllability.  The major research objective is to establish a fundamental understanding of mechanisms involved in the photon-enabled atomic drilling process responsible for the formation of porous graphene frameworks.  A computational model capable of predicting photon-enabled bond excitation and dissociation as affected by the laser processing parameters will be developed.  Microstructure characterization and electrochemical property testing will be conducted to establish the process-structure-property relationship.  This research contributes to advances in photon-based manufacturing technology development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project aimed to develop a novel method to enhance supercapacitor performance using photon-enabled atomic drilling (PEAD) of graphene. Supercapacitors are highly efficient energy storage devices, but they are often limited by lower energy storage capacities compared to batteries. Our approach involves using lasers to drill precise, nanoscale holes in graphene, which is a highly conductive and lightweight material. By creating these "holey graphene" structures, we aimed to increase the surface area and improve the electrochemical properties, resulting in enhanced energy and power densities for supercapacitors.

 

 Intellectual Merit:

The primary goal of this project was to understand how photon-based drilling can alter the structure of graphene at the atomic level and improve its performance in supercapacitor applications. Over the project’s lifespan, we successfully demonstrated the capability of PEAD to create uniform nanoholes in graphene, increasing its surface area and optimizing ion transport. This directly led to improved energy storage capacity and charge-discharge efficiency of supercapacitors. Through rigorous computational modeling and experimentation, we were able to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of the PEAD process. We used computational tools such as density functional theory (DFT) and molecular dynamics simulations to model photon-graphene interactions and predict how laser parameters affect the formation of nanoholes. These predictions were validated through experiments that revealed the relationships between laser intensity, exposure time, and the resulting hole size and electrochemical properties. The PEAD-fabricated holey graphene electrodes demonstrated a significant improvement in energy and power densities, outperforming traditional graphene-based electrodes.

 

 Broader Impacts:

The findings from this project have the potential to significantly advance energy storage technologies. By improving the performance of supercapacitors, we can develop faster-charging, longer-lasting energy storage systems for a variety of applications, including electric vehicles, consumer electronics, and renewable energy systems. The enhanced energy and power densities of the PEAD-fabricated supercapacitors offer a pathway towards more sustainable and efficient energy storage solutions. Additionally, this project provided valuable training and education opportunities for students involved in the research. Graduate and undergraduate students were trained in advanced computational modeling, laser processing techniques, and electrochemical testing, equipping them with essential skills for future careers in energy storage, materials science, and nanotechnology. The project also contributed to the dissemination of knowledge through journal publications and conference presentations, ensuring that the research outcomes reached both the scientific community and the broader public. Overall, this research has made substantial contributions to the fields of nanomaterials, advanced manufacturing, and energy storage. By establishing the PEAD process as a viable method for enhancing supercapacitor performance, we have opened up new possibilities for the development of next-generation energy storage devices with improved efficiency and functionality.

 

 Conclusion:

This collaborative research project successfully achieved its objectives, advancing the understanding of photon-enabled atomic drilling of graphene and its application in supercapacitors. By demonstrating significant improvements in energy and power density through precise control over graphene’s nanostructure, this research lays the groundwork for future innovations in energy storage technology. The knowledge and expertise gained through this project will continue to benefit the scientific community and contribute to the development of more efficient, sustainable energy storage systems in the future.

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2024
Modified by: Yongfeng Lu
